utterances: Well, Michael Lewis, she's talking about the height of the boom there.
She is talking about the height of the boom.
The - a period in which Icelanders had borrowed huge sums of money to buy their - to buy things in Iceland, so driving the price of everything up.
I mean, it's - you know, what intrigued me about the place was that it was first, an example of American, kind of, business intellectual influence gone wrong.
But second, it was a more extreme version of what we're going through here.
And the - in the boom - which is all about leverage, all about people buying things with borrowed money - the Icelandic stock market went up nine times.
The property market tripled.
The wealth in the place went through the roof.
And so, it did become, I'm sure - I didn't travel there when it was expensive, but I'm sure it was very expensive for someone coming from outside to go - to visit.
Kirsten, would you go back?
I suspect things are a lot cheaper now.
Yeah.
I mean, I - the reason, actually, I made my trip so short, I actually ended up going to Copenhagen quickly afterwards because I couldn't afford all of the prices there.
But I would love to go back.

And one other funny anecdote - I drove out to the middle of nowhere to a hot springs, and the only cars there were giant Hummers, and the price of gas at that point, I think, was probably $15 a gallon.
So, it was a little funny, I have to say.
Okay.
Kirsten, thanks very much for the call.
Michael Lewis is talking earlier about how Iceland has been so clever in the past, for example, an important member of NATO and its contribution is its geography.
It has no armed forces whatsoever.

It's protected by the other members of NATO, and its geography is it sits in the middle of the shipping routes of the North Atlantic, and the center of the so-called GIUK gap that blocks the exits into the North Atlantic.
Well, that's enough for NATO to consider it a very valuable member of the alliance.
And there's an airbase there, too, and some other things - but no Icelandic soldiers.
We're talking about Michael Lewis' article ""Frozen Assets"" in the April issue of Vanity Fair magazine.
You're listening to TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
And let's see if we can go now to Richard.
Richard is calling us from Kalamazoo.
Hi, Neal.
Hi, Richard.
I was there about almost 10 years ago.
And to kind of concur with the previous caller, it was very beautiful, it was a nice little excursion.
But I was eating on an Indian restaurant one night, and the owner came over and we started talking.
She had a home at North Carolina.
She was Indian.
And I said, well, what are you doing in Reykjavik?
And she said, well, I have this restaurant and my kids go to school here.
And I said, really?
And I said, why, you know, Iceland?
She said, well, you know, it's so safe here.
There's no crime.
When I leave for work, my kids go off to school - I don't even lock the doors.
And I thought that was really interesting.
I thought, you know, hey, here's a nice idyllic place that you can, you know, live and not worry about anybody breaking in.
So, I know recently they've had problems with, you know, some violence over there.
That's one of the things, Michael Lewis, you write about.
What do I write about, violence?
Yeah - about that different sense of security, because people are putting money in their mattresses.
Well, this is - it's - this is - yes.
When the banks collapsed, the - I met, in fact, I spent some time with one young banker, who saw it was all going to come a cropper, thought that the local currency was going to be worth nothing.
And he, like a number of other clever people, went and took as many dollars and yen and Swiss francs and euros, other currencies out of the banks.
He took them home and he hid it in a board game.
But people were hoarding food, and people were concerned.
His concern - he had a very odd concern.
He was so unused to having large amounts of cash on him because the whole place functions with credit cards.
People pay the most trivial transactions with their credit cards.
That he was sure that once he had this huge sack of cash, he was down to be mugged.
And he kept going on and on about how he assumed that plane-loads of muggers were coming over from New York to take his money.
And so he didn't want - in fact, he wouldn't let us put his picture in Vanity Fair because he was afraid someone would connect him to the board game full of cash and his home would be robbed.
But I'm not sure there's a huge amount of crime.
I mean, their social problems are trivial compared to most countries.
It's - what's happened there is more of an identity crisis.
I mean, they're technically bankrupt.
They owe people all kinds of money.
I'm not sure they're ever going to repay it.
But it's much more this vast social embarrassment.
They thought they were really good at being investment bankers.
They thought that they had this incredibly slick operation up and running, and they thought they were, you know, all of a sudden they were all these young millionaires wandering around.
A man from the IMF told me when he went in there to try to sort out the mess, he said, it's the most incredible thing I've ever seen.
He said, it's not a country - Iceland is not a country - it's a hedge fund.
It's a hedge that's collapsed.
He said there are all these young people who dressed in black and just started doing trades.
And now, there's - they're coming to grips with the idea that this wasn't -they weren't so good at this and this wasn't such a good idea.
And so there're, you know, there're protests in the streets; there's some trivial violence between police and protesters, or has been; the governments stepped down and been replaced.
But it's not - Iceland is not - it's not a dangerous place.
I mean, the most dangerous thing that's going to happen to you in Iceland is you're going to drive, you know, drive out in the country and get lost.
The other aspect of this that I found truly fascinating was the division of the sexes on this, that the - all of this boom was fueled by men.
Yes.
This was a, you know, when I got there, I was surprised to find - lots of things about the place surprised me, because I've never been there before.
One was - all right, it's a nation of 300,000 people.
It's Peoria, Illinois, but it's got four major political parties.
Now, you know, that suggests either like a talent for disagreement or just nobody is listening to each other.
And there are even some minor political parties, so think about that, all right?
I don't know how many people in each party, and you got to discount the children and - but anyway.

So, one of these political parties that had been in power basically throughout this whole mess and before, and it arranged to privatize the banks, the Independence Party, is party almost entirely of men.
It's a fishermen's party.
And the men had vast confidence in their abilities to triumph in a global financial system, and the men were behind all the big moves that happened in banks, in the government.
And now that it's all come a cropper, the women are taking over.
The women are basically sussing out that the men completely screwed up.
And the party that's coming to power are the Social Democrats.
Their leader is a woman, a lesbian, the first openly gay head of state in the world.
And, you know, her first acts are, among other things, ban strip clubs.
But the women have walked in and said, you know, no more, this is - all of this financial disaster was, at bottom, all about male overconfidence, and we're going to put an end to it.
And you can read all about in the April issue of Vanity Fair magazine.
The article is called ""Frozen Assets."" Michael Lewis is its author.
Thanks very much for being with us.
Thanks for having me.
Well over a million people flooded Washington, D.C.
yesterday to be part of the inauguration of President Barack Obama.
It would an understatement to say that the nation's capital was busy or crowded.
Longs lines, crowded trains cars and well, bone-chilling cold, still crowds packed the National Mall and the parade route on Pennsylvania Avenue.
Many never made it past security checkpoints though.
They traveled here by car, bus, train, and plane.
Now, a day later, many are heading home.
So did you make the trip to Washington?
Was it worth it?
Tell us about your experience at the inauguration and whether you've warmed up yet.
Email, talk@npr.org.
Joining us now is Dawn Turner Trice, a columnist for The Chicago Tribune, a familiar voice to our listeners.
Nice to have you back on the program.
Thank you so much.
And you're on your way back to Chicago?
Yes, yes, after an amazing few days.
An amazing few days.
You driving back?
No, I'm at the airport.
And was the trip worth it?
I'm sorry?
Was your trip here worth it?
Oh, it was absolutely worth it.
You know, everyone has spoken about how history(ph) it was yesterday.
But I tell you, I was on the - I had the best seat in the house, one of the best seats in the house.
I could've tossed up an apple to the president had he asked.
I was so close and - but just when I turned around and looked at the crowd, it was just astounding.
Really, I don't know.
I can't speak enough about just the number of people, it almost looked computer generated.
The number of people who were there was amazing.
And was everybody fairly well-behaved?
It was incredible.
The latest report said there were no arrest and you know, no big brouhaha.
It was just - it was astounding.
Even on the flight here Saturday - on Sunday, I was just amazed by the number of people who were talking about it.
I was sitting next to someone who was just giddy.
She was so excited.

She was coming from Chicago, as well, and it was just - and then the person in the seat in front of us turned around and chimed in, and it was like this big, you know, this little pajama party almost.

I've been really moved by, you know, as a journalist, you're supposed to be so objective and not kind of feel anything, but it's really - even more so than the whole inauguration but the people - it's been amazing just to kind of feel what they're feeling.
And if you were in the crowd, maybe it wasn't quite so cold.
Well, it was cold.
(Soundbite of laughter)
I wrote this morning that I've never been more aware of my fingers and my toes.
It was extremely cold but, once Barack Obama, President Obama, stood before us and the main event got under way, it was, you know, things started to warm a bit.
And I understand, you're flying out of Baltimore, BWI, which says it's near Washington, but really isn't.
How was it getting to and from the airport, getting around the city?
You know, earlier this morning, I'm told that traffic was just amazingly tight.
But I sailed here.
I left early, and I thought it was going to be, you know, a huge challenge and it wasn't.
So I'm here at the airport now and no lines at all.
No lines at all?
So it's going to be quick.
